body: This is the failing test on Travis. I'll try to build locally in a bit here and see if it happens for me.
nit: capitalize "The"
`startsWith`
kill empty line :)

Since this can be called with multiple arguments now, let's add the version to this string.

``` java
"Compilation API $version found!"
```
awesome!

It's a common enough pattern in the file that I'm tempted to call it in every other place in this file that needs to install a package. Abstract out "Compilation API" to another parameter. Maybe too far?
I like that, but save it for a follow-up PR>
I think this needs to be double quotes for Groovy to do the variable replacement.
This should be using the `System` class I created and have it passed into the constructor. This will allow testing to verify this behavior works correctly.
Why?
Why add "jcenter()"? When adding 'classpath 'org.gradle.api.plugins:gradle-nexus-plugin:0.7.1', it was not finding it in mavenCentral.
Nothing like a nice fractured ecosystem. Sigh.
Hah. I understand.
Seems like an erroneous edit.

body: Why have two mechanisms for the same thing?
This is not a valid literal. You need to surround it with quotes.
@JakeWharton thanks, just pushed a fix

I have moved adding android repository url above dependency scan routine.
This is necessary because now we are not just parsing strings at the `build.gradle` file, but gradle actually tries to resolve dependencies. And to be able to resolve the "up-to-date" case gradle needs m2repository link to resolve support library if it's repository is present.
We can trust gradle resolving mechanism that if it thinks that dependency is resolved, then we are all set. No need to make additional check.
This line will make internet connection if necessary. Is there any way to limit configurations scope or make a batch resolution? Will this call be cached at the daemon level?

To avoid making internet connection at the tests. I have created localMaven repo with nested library.
Bad thing I had to copy-paste it through "up-to-date", "missing", "outdated" fixtures.
Why is this included in the PR?

Hmm, odd. When I first tried, `./gradlew check` did not even start to execute because Gradle could not download `gradle-nexus-plugin-0.7.1`. I just tried again, and now it works. Probably some temporary network hiccup. Anyway version 0.7.1 seems quite outdated and / or the version scheme seems to have changed. [Bintray search](https://bintray.com/search?query=gradle-nexus-plugin) shows `org.gradle.api.plugins:gradle-nexus-plugin:0.3` or `com.bmuschko:gradle-nexus-plugin:2.3.1` to be the latest version (both from Benjamin Muschko), but the latter has a more recent release date. Strangely enough, I do not see version 0.7.1 on Bintray.

I'll update the commit message to not say anymore that it did not work without this change.
Huh. Weird.
FYI, my PR #111 avoids the need for a hard-coded constant by looking at the version from the list of available updates.
